title: Text Title
displayTitle: You play an important role in supporting your mentee's Individual Development Plan (IDP) creation.
body: To help your mentee prepare for this important discussion, remember: it's their plan. It's up to them to create and implement it. As their mentor, you can ask challenging questions, help them hone their plan of attack, and support them.
instruction: Next, meet with your mentee to test-drive their career plan and their IDP before they talk with their manager.

title: Navigate here
displayTitle: After you review those pages in your workbook and meet to talk about career planning, you can move on to the fifth module.

title: Lesson Checklist
displayTitle: Get ready to have your next career conversations.
body: Regardless of your role, this is a good time to reflect on your own career as an employee. Follow the steps below before your next career discussions.

_items.title: Fill out the SWOO worksheet on page 21 of your workbook.
Complete the Gap Analysis on page 23 of your workbook to understand how the gaps between current state and desired future state relate to career development.
Complete the IDP on pages 25-26 of your workbook to establish a plan for moving your career forward.

title: Text Title
displayTitle: What’s next? Complete an Individual Development Plan (IDP).
body:
Consider the Gap Analysis and the other activities you've done so far in this series. Use what you've learned and discovered to complete your Individual Development Plan (IDP) and be prepared to share it with your manager. Be ready to talk with your manager about how they can support you in your plan. 


  See page 24 of your workbook to prepare for creating your IDP. After this, you can find an IDP template on pages 25-26 of your workbook. Click the link below to access this workbook section.
instruction: Before taking your IDP to your manager, talk through it with your mentor and make any edits that might be necessary after your discussion.

title: Select Other Two Roles 1
instruction: If you'd like, you can review what the other roles learned in this module.

_items.text: Manager
Mentor

title: Text Title
displayTitle: Once you have an idea of where you want to go with your career, make a plan.
body: You can take your career in a number of directions from here, but you should examine each of your potential paths to identify strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and obstacles (SWOO) along that path.
instruction: Check out page 21 of your workbook to try a SWOO worksheet.

title: Text Title
displayTitle: Planning for the future can be challenging.
body: It can be hard to plan your career too far into the future. The pace of change is always so fast that such planning can quickly become irrelevant. Our jobs morph and evolve quickly even as we progress through our own development. We also have to consider organizational restructuring, emerging technology, and a number of other variables that can impact roles and career paths.

title: Card Drop Title
body: Drag each card and drop it in either the “do” or “don’t” category.

_items.text: Expect the best and challenge people to succeed.
Make promises.
Create a plan that fits the employee’s path.
Help employees clarify goals and identify development steps.
Support plans that seem likely to fail.
Prevent an employee from leaving your organization.
Select a few achievable actions and developmental assignments.
Help employees navigate the organization.
Take over the process for the employee.
Use tools that are available to you.
Allow good intentions to substitute for a SMART plan.

title: Text Title

title: Select Other Two Roles 2
instruction: If you'd like, you can review what the other roles learned in this module.

_items.text: Manager

title: Select Role - Completion Trigger
instruction: Select your role to learn about how you'll engage in career planning.

_items.text: Employee
Mentor
Manager

title: Text Title
displayTitle: Support your employee as they make their plan.
body: If an employee has clear values, strengths, and passions—as well as knowledge about possible future opportunities and associated requirements throughout the organization—then planning is a fairly straightforward effort.

_incorrect.notFinal: Not quite. You can develop a plan that focuses on skills, competencies, and tools that align with your passions. That way, no matter what changes at the organization, in the industry, or around the world, your plan will still make sense for you—because it's always relevant to who you are as a person and as a professional.
_incorrect.final: Not quite. You can develop a plan that focuses on skills, competencies, and tools that align with your passions. That way, no matter what changes at the organization, in the industry, or around the world, your plan will still make sense for you—because it's always relevant to who you are as a person and as a professional.

_partlyCorrect.notFinal: Not quite. You can develop a plan that focuses on skills, competencies, and tools that align with your passions. That way, no matter what changes at the organization, in the industry, or around the world, your plan will still make sense for you—because it's always relevant to who you are as a person and as a professional.
_partlyCorrect.final: Not quite. You can develop a plan that focuses on skills, competencies, and tools that align with your passions. That way, no matter what changes at the organization, in the industry, or around the world, your plan will still make sense for you—because it's always relevant to who you are as a person and as a professional.

_feedback.correct: That's right. You can develop a plan that focuses on skills, competencies, and tools that align with your passions. That way, no matter what changes at the organization, in the industry, or around the world, your plan will still make sense for you—because it's always relevant to who you are as a person and as a professional.

_items.text: Don't plan—just take opportunities as they come to you.
Develop competencies that prepare you for a variety of possible roles.
Just use your personal time to pursue your interests.
Revise your detailed plan every time a change happens.

title: Text Title
displayTitle: Individual Development Planning: remember it's the employee's plan.
body:
The planning conversation is a manager’s opportunity to help the employee take control of their career in a purposeful, thoughtful manner. It is up to the employee, however, to create and implement it. Managers are there to support them. 


When an employee has decided which career pathway best fits them, the next step is to analyze the gap in skills, knowledge, and experience between their current assets and those required to be eligible for the targeted role. 


After this section, your employee will complete their Individual Development Plan (IDP) and bring it to you.
instruction: To prepare for an IDP discussion with your employee, review the IDP discussion guide, as well as the IDP itself, in the attachment below or on pages 24-26 of your workbook.

title: Text Title
instruction: Jump to page 22 of your workbook to learn more about setting SMART goals and doing SMART planning.

title: Text Title
displayTitle: Gap analysis is an important part of planning and setting goals, too.
body:
Gap analysis is an examination of current performance and skills, and then identifying if there are missing pieces between that current state and the desired future state. 


You can ask the following questions to spot gaps in career development:

  • What capabilities are required for the future role?
  • What are the current capabilities and assets?
  • Compare the future role versus the current role, and identify key differences.
instruction: For a thorough gap analysis exercise, go to page 23 in your workbook. Be prepared to talk with the employee about what they identified as gaps and how they can address those gaps.

title: Flow Chart Title
displayTitle: Keep the following best practices in mind as you consider your career planning and mobility.
body: Click the down arrow to review all three reminders.

_items.title: BE SPECIFIC.
_items.body: Always include specifics when planning development activities (dates, times) to ensure that you will follow through.
Conduct informational interviews to do a reality check and see what the roles that interest you are really like.
_items.title: CONDUCT INTERVIEWS.

_items.body: If you are considering a dramatic change (moving into a first-time management role or changing fields), take extra time and effort to test your preconceptions.
_items.title: TEST IDEAS.

title: DISABLE POP-UP
displayTitle: A successful career journey begins with proactive planning.
body:
Careers do evolve on their own, and sometimes things work out just as we hoped—or even better than we could have planned.


But, on closer inspection, most satisfying careers that seem to have just happened were usually the result of hard work and risk-taking to develop skills and follow passions that aligned with a real organizational need.

title: Media Carousel Title
body: SMART is an acronym used to describe career goals and planning. Each letter of the word "SMART" stands for different criteria that will enable you to develop clear, focused, and valuable goals for your career.
instruction: Click the left and right arrows below to learn more about each item, and follow the SMART criteria to write your goals and milestones.

_items.body: Make sure goals are clearly defined and focused.
_items.title:
S stands for...   
SPECIFIC

_items.body: Establish your definition of success on your goal, and determine which activities and milestones you can use to evaluate your progress along the way.
_items.title:
M stands for...   
MEASURABLE

_items.body: Make sure goals and plans are achievable within the given timeframe.
_items.title:
A stands for...   
ATTAINABLE

_items.body: Ensure that goals and plans are an appropriate focus for the specific individual.
_items.title:
R stands for...   
RELEVANT

_items.body: Give yourself a timeline and a deadline that will motivate you to stay on track and keep pushing forward in a timely manner - and try to keep it realistic so you don't get discouraged.
_items.title:
T stands for...   
TIME-BOUND

title: Text Title
displayTitle: At this organization, we prioritize internal mobility.
body: Our goal is to enable equitable lateral movement and career development. You’ll have the opportunity to pursue your areas of interest across departmental functions.
instruction: Visit your company’s internal job board as it will provide employees with information on open positions. Use this to explore available job opportunities that match your career development and aspirations.

title: Select Other Two Roles 3
instruction: If you'd like, you can review what the other roles learned in this module.

_items.text: Mentor
Employee

title: Text Title
displayTitle: At this stage in the series, your mentee is working on a plan for their career development.
body: You can support your mentee by being a sounding board for them as they develop their plan. Let them run things by you, and give them your honest feedback.
instruction: Use page 23 of your workbook to start planning a conversation with your mentee.

_items.itemTitle: Download "Preparing Your IDP" & IDP Template
Download "Conducting an IDP Discussion" & IDP Template

title: Text Title
displayTitle: Gap analysis is an important part of planning and setting goals, too.
body:
A gap analysis allows you to examine your current performance and skills, and then identify if there are missing pieces between the current state and the desired future state. 


You can ask the following questions to spot gaps in your career development:

  • What capabilities are required for the future role?
  • What are the current capabilities and assets?
  • Compare the future role versus the current role, and identify key differences.
instruction: Go to page 23 in your workbook and complete a gap analysis. Share this with your manager and/or mentor to get their feedback.

_items.itemTitle: Close module and return to ITS Learning Portal
